text.front:
Bioorg. Med. Chem. 111 (2024) 117841
Available online 18 July 2024
0968-0896/© 2024 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd. This is an open access article under the CC BY license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).
3-Tetrazolyl-β-carboline derivatives as potential neuroprotective agents
João L.P. Ribeiro a , Inês Costa b, c , Renata Silva b, c , Susana M.M. Lopes a , Lucília Saraiva d , Teresa
M.V.D. Pinho e Melo a, *
a University of Coimbra, Coimbra Chemistry Centre-Institute of Molecular Sciences, and Department of Chemistry, 3004-535 Coimbra, Portugal
b UCIBIO -Applied Molecular Biosciences Unit, Laboratory of Toxicology, Department of Biological Sciences, Faculty of Pharmacy, Porto University, Porto, Portugal
c Associate Laboratory i4HB -Institute for Health and Bioeconomy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Porto University, Porto, Portugal
d LAQV/REQUIMTE, Laboratory of Microbiology, Department of Biological Sciences, Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Porto, Rua Jorge Viterbo Ferreira, 228, 4050-
313 Porto, Portugal
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords:
β-Carbolines
Tetrazoles
Hetero-Diels-Alder
Neuroprotective Agents
Parkinson's Disease
A B S T R A C T
3-Tetrazolyl-β-carbolines were prepared by the Pictet-Spengler approach using a tryptophan analogue as building
block, in which the carboxylic acid was replaced by the bioisosteric tetrazole group. Knowing that β-carbolines
are often associated with psychopharmacological effects, the study of the 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines as potential
neuroprotective agents against Parkinson's disease was investigated. The evaluation of neuroprotective effects
against 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridin-1-ium (MPP + )-induced cytotoxicity allowed to identify compounds with
relevant neuroprotective activity. One derivative, 3-(1-benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(p-dimethylaminophenyl)-
β-carboline, stood out for its low cytotoxicity and excellent performance, preventing cell death induced by this
neurotoxin. The most promising compounds were also evaluated for their neuroprotective properties against iron
(III)-induced cytotoxicity. However, only one 3-tetrazolyl-β-carboline derivative slightly reduced iron-induced
cytotoxicity. Overall, the neuroprotective properties of 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines have been demonstrated and
this finding may contribute to the development of new therapies for Parkinson's disease.
text.body:
1. Introduction
β-Carbolines constitute a category of both natural and synthetic
compounds comprised by an indole-based structure featuring a 9H-
pyrido[3,4-b]indole scaffold. They exhibit diverse biological activ-
ities, 1,2 including anti-HIV, 3 antimalarial, 4 and anticancer properties, 5-9
among others. 10-13
In recent years, numerous synthetic methods have been used to
prepare new β-carboline derivatives, but the formation of tetrahydro-
β-carboline intermediates through the Pictet-Spengler reaction, fol-
lowed by their oxidation, has been the method of choice. 14,15 In our
research group, we have extensively studied the reactivity of nitro-
soalkenes toward heterocycles, 16 and explored its potential application
in the synthesis of new tryptamines. Nitrosoalkenes are generated in situ
by treating α-bromooximes with sodium carbonate and participate in
hetero-Diels-Alder reactions with indoles. The 1,2-oxazine cycloadducts
undergo ring-opening affording 3-alkylated indoles incorporating an
oxime moiety. The open-chain oxime is then reduced to yield the desired
tryptamines. 6,7,17-19 In this context, tryptophan analogues, in which the
carboxylic acid was replaced by the bioisosteric tetrazole group, were
synthesised and used as building block for the synthesis of novel 3-tet-
razolyl-β-carbolines. 6,7
The synthesized derivatives were tested for their activity against a
wide range of cancer cell lines. β-Carboline 1, showed high selectivity
for cancer cells, with IC 50 values below 8 μM against pancreatic
adenocarcinoma (PAN-1), melanoma (A375), hepatocarcinoma
(HEPG2) and breast adenocarcinoma (MCF-7) cell lines. The fluorine-
containing 3-tetrazolyl-β-carboline 2 proved to be active against glio-
blastoma (U251), breast adenocarcinoma (MCF-7), renal adenocarci-
noma (786-0), ovarian carcinoma (OVAR-3) and leukaemia (K-562)
tumour cell lines with GI 50 values below 2 μM (Figure 1). 6,7
Within their wide range of documented biological activities, both
synthetic and natural β-carbolines are often associated with psycho-
pharmacological effects. 10,11
Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by
the disruption of the dopaminergic pathway, resulting in movement
disorders, postural instability, tremors, and muscular rigidness. This
condition is progressive, with symptoms worsening over time, which
text.front:
* Corresponding author.
E-mail address: tmelo@ci.uc.pt (T.M.V.D. Pinho e Melo).
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/bmc
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bmc.2024.117841
Received 12 April 2024; Received in revised form 11 July 2024; Accepted 15 July 2024
text.body:
greatly reduces the patient's life expectancy and quality of life. Par-
kinson's disease is currently incurable, with the treatments available
aiming only at symptom relief and managing the patient's quality of life.
Furthermore, some individuals have a higher genetic susceptibility to
developing the disease, in which case several prophylactic measures can
be taken to prevent and/or slow the progression of the disease. 20
Several studies have been reported on the pharmacological activity
of β-carboline derivatives against neuropsychiatric disorders, namely
depression, 21-23 Alzheimer's disease, 24-26 epilepsy, 27,28 and Parkinson's
disease. 29-31
In view of the known activity of β-carboline derivatives against
neuropsychiatric diseases, we decided to study 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines
as potential neuroprotective agents against Parkinson's disease, using
differentiated SH-SY5Y cells as in vitro model.
2. Results and discussion
2.1. Chemistry
Initially, the tryptophan analogue 5 was prepared according to pre-
viously described procedures. 6,18 The synthesis of the open chain oxime
4 was achieved by bromination of acetyltetrazole 3, followed by oxi-
mation, and finally hetero-Diels-Alder reaction of the in situ generated
nitrosoalkene with indole and subsequent 1,2-oxazine ring-opening. 18
Reduction of the oxime moiety of compound 4 with Zn in formic acid
afforded the target tryptamine 5. 6 The Pictet-Spengler reaction of amino
tetrazole 5 with aromatic aldehydes (m-nitrobenzaldehyde, o-chlor-
obenzaldehyde and p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde), in the presence of
trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), gave tetrahydro-β-carbolines 6 in yields
ranging from 34% to 84% (Scheme 1). The tetrahydro-β-carbolines 6a-b
were isolated as mixtures of cis/trans isomers, while trans-6c was iso-
lated as single isomer. The oxidation of tetrahydro-β-carbolines 6 was
carried out with sulphur in refluxing dimethylformamide for 24 h,
affording β-carbolines 7a-c in good yields (56-63%). The β-carbolines
were purified by recrystallization in methanol, which contributed to the
overall efficiency of the synthetic procedure.
2.2. Biological studies
2.2.1. Evaluation of compounds' cytotoxicity
The cytotoxicity of the compounds under study towards differenti-
ated SH-SY5Y cells was evaluated, 24 h after exposure, by the neutral
red (NR) uptake and resazurin (REZ) reduction assays. As shown in
Figure 2, compounds 1 and 2 proved to be the most cytotoxic among the
tested compounds, with significant cytotoxic effects being detected for
concentrations equal to or higher than 10 μM. In fact, in the case of
compound 1, NR uptake significantly decreased to 85.6, 81.3 and
65.9%, 24 h after exposure to 10, 25 and 50 μM, respectively, compared
to control (untreated cells). In the REZ reduction assay similar results
were observed, although the cytotoxic effects were only significant for
the two highest concentrations (REZ reduction significantly decreased to
74.0 and 59.3%, 24 h after exposure to 25 and 50 μM). For compound 2,
the results of the two cytotoxicity assays were also highly concordant.
Indeed, in the NR uptake assay, the lysosomal accumulation of NR
significantly decreased to 83.6, 70.5 and 56.1%, 24 h after exposure to
10, 25 and 50 μM, while REZ reduction significantly decreased to 80.0,
62.2 and 48.5%, 24 h after exposure to the same concentrations. For
compound 7a, no significant cytotoxic effects were detected 24 h after
exposure to any of the tested concentrations, as evaluated by the NR
uptake assay. However, a minor but significant decrease in REZ reduc-
tion was observed upon exposure to the highest tested concentration
(REZ reduction significantly decreased to 92.6%, 24 h after exposure to
50 μM of compound 7a, when compared to control cells). Concerning
compound 7b, although no significant effects were detected in the REZ
reduction assay, a significant decrease in NR uptake was observed for
the two highest concentrations tested (NR uptake significantly
decreased to 84.0 and 81.7% 24 h after exposure to 25 and 50 μM of
compound 7b, respectively). Finally, for compound 7c, similarly to
compound 7b, despite the lack of significant effects detected by the REZ
reduction assay, the NR uptake significantly decreased 24 h after
exposure to the highest tested concentration (NR uptake significantly
decreased to 80.5%, 24 h after exposure to 50 μM of compound 7c).
Overall, compounds 7a, 7b and 7c can be considered non-cytotoxic
Figure 1. Structure of 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines with promising anti-
cancer activity.
Scheme 1. Synthesis of novel 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines.
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
Figure 2. Cytotoxicity of the compounds towards differentiated SH-SY5Y cells, evaluated by the neutral red uptake (A) and resazurin reduction (B) assays, 24 h after
exposure. Results are presented as mean + SD from 5 independent experiments, performed in triplicate. Statistical comparisons were performed using the One-way
ANOVA followed by the Dunnett's multiple comparisons test [***p < 0.001; ****p < 0.0001 vs. control cells].
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
at concentrations up to 10 μM, whereas for compounds 1 and 2 the
highest concentration considered non-cytotoxic is 5 μM. These concen-
trations were thus selected for the assessment of the compounds' neu-
roprotective effects.
The ability of the compounds to induce reactive oxygen species
(ROS) overproduction was also evaluated 24 h after exposure. However,
as shown in Figure 3, a small but significant increase in ROS intracellular
levels was only observed 24 h after exposure to the highest concentra-
tion of compound 2 (2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein, DCF, fluorescence
increased to 108.2%, 24 h after exposure to 50 μM of 2, when compared
to control cells).
2.2.2. Evaluation of the neuroprotective effects of compounds
Neuroprotective effects against MPP + -induced cytotoxicity.
1-Methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) is a meperi-
dine analogue, produced as a by-product in the process of synthesizing
1-methyl-4-phenyl-propionoxzy-piperidine. Once inside the body, due
to its lipophilicity, it crosses the blood-brain-barrier (BBB) into the
central nervous system (CNS), where the MAO-B enzyme, secreted by
glial cells, converts MPTP into a metabolite, 1-methyl-4-phenyl-2,3-
dihydropyridine (MPDP + ), and subsequently to the final toxic metabo-
lite, 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridin-1-ium (MPP + ). MPTP itself is not toxic in
the brain, and it requires the process of biotransformation to form the
toxic metabolite. 32-37 MPP + can exert its toxicity on the mitochondria,
where it inhibits the cellular respiration through the blockage of the
electron transport enzyme NADH-ubiquinone oxidoreductase (complex
I), inhibiting the electron transport and thus leading to an energy failure
with ATP depletion, and to an increase in the formation of free radi-
cals. 38,39 The specific MPP + -induced dopaminergic cytotoxicity has
been commonly used to investigate the potential of new neuroprotective
agents, being this neurotoxin largely used, in vitro and in vivo, to mimic
Parkinson's disease. 40 The neuroprotective effects of compounds against
Figure 3. Intracellular levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS), evaluated in differentiated SH-SY5Y cells, 24 h after exposure to the compounds, using the DCFH-DA
probe. Results are presented as mean + SD from at least 4 independent experiments, performed in triplicate. Statistical comparisons were performed using the One-
way ANOVA followed by the Dunnett's multiple comparisons test [****p < 0.0001 vs. control cells].
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
MPP + -induced cytotoxicity were assessed, by the NR uptake assay, 24 h
after exposure of differentiated SH-SY5Y cells to the chemical aggressor
(up to 1000 μM) in the presence or absence of non-cytotoxic concen-
trations of the compounds under study (1, 2.5, 5 and 10 μM). All com-
pounds were tested at 1, 2.5 and 5 μM, and additionally 7a, 7b and 7c
were also tested at 10 μM given the lack of cytotoxic effects at this
concentration. As observed in Figure 4, although for 7a no significant
effects were observed, and for 7b a small but significant reduction of
MPP + -induced cytotoxicity was detected, particularly for the highest
concentration, for compounds 1, 2 and 7c a significant decrease in the
cytotoxicity of the chemical aggressor was observed. For compound 1,
NR uptake significantly increased to 91.4, 92,1 and 93.5% 24 h after
exposure to 500 μM MPP + in the presence of 1, 2.5 and 5 μM of com-
pound 1, respectively, when compared to 83.3% observed for 500 μM
MPP + alone. Similar results were obtained 24 h after exposure to the
highest concentration of the neurotoxin, with NR uptake significantly
increasing to 87.1, 84.6 and 89.1% 24 h after exposure to 1000 μM
MPP + in the presence of 1, 2.5 and 5 μM of compound 1, respectively,
when compared to 75.8% observed for 1000 μM MPP + alone. Regarding
compound 2, when exposed to 500 μM MPP + , the neuroprotective ef-
fects were only observed for the 2.5 μM concentration (NR uptake
significantly increased to 91.4% 24 h after exposure to 500 μM MPP + in
the presence of 2.5 μM of compound 2, when compared to 83.9%
observed for 500 μM MPP + alone). However, when the highest con-
centration of the chemical aggressor was used, a significant reduction in
MPP + -induced cytotoxicity was observed in the presence of compound
2, for all the concentrations tested (NR uptake significantly increased to
84.8, 83.4 and 83.2% 24 h after exposure to 1000 μM MPP + in the
presence of 1, 2.5 and 5 μM of compound 2, respectively, when
compared to 76.2% observed for 1000 μM MPP + alone). For both
Figure 4. Neuroprotective effects of compounds against MPP + -induced cytotoxicity evaluated in differentiated SH-SY5Y cells 24 h after exposure to the aggressor in
the presence or absence of compounds. Results are presented as mean + SD from at least 4 independent experiments, performed in triplicate. Statistical comparisons
were performed using the Two-way ANOVA followed by the Tukey's multiple comparisons test [ ## p < 0.01; ### p < 0.001; #### p < 0.0001 vs. in the absence of
MPP + ; *p < 0.05; **p < 0.01; ****p < 0.0001, for comparisons between treatments [MPP + alone, MPP + + Compound (1, 2.5, 5 or 10 μM)], at each MPP +
concentration].
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
compounds 1 and 2, the observed neuroprotection was not dependent
on the concentration of compound tested. Finally, compound 7c
demonstrated the highest protective effect, at least at 1 and 2.5 μM
concentrations, against the cytotoxicity induced by the MPP + neuro-
toxin, with a significant reduction in MPP + -induced cell death, being an
effect observed at all concentrations of the chemical aggressor. Note-
worthy, the observed neuroprotective effects were more significant for
the lowest concentration tested of 7c (1 μM) (Figure 4). Indeed, NR
significantly increased to 97.8, 92.3 and 85.8% 24 h after exposure to
500 μM MPP + in the presence of 1, 2.5 and 5 μM of compound 7c,
respectively, when compared to 81.1% observed for 500 μM MPP +
alone. Notably, no significant effects in NR uptake were detected be-
tween differentiated SH-SY5Y cells exposed to 500 μM MPP + in the
presence of 1 μM of compound 7c and control cell (without MPP + ),
which highlights the remarkable 7c-mediated protection against MPP + -
induced cytotoxicity, completely preventing the cell death induced by
the aggressor. When the chemical aggressor was tested at the highest
concentration, NR significantly increased to 90.3 and 83.6% 24 h after
exposure to 1000 μM MPP + in the presence of 1 and 2.5 μM of compound
7c, respectively, when compared to 75.0% observed for 1000 μM MPP +
alone.
The existence of a more pronounced neuroprotective effect of com-
pound 7c against MPP + -induced cytotoxicity at lower concentrations,
potentially including its ability to restore mitochondrial function and
enhance energy metabolism, may be due to the existence of an optimal
concentration range to ensure selective targeting of relevant cell sig-
nalling pathways, avoidance of off-target effects, and maintenance of
redox balance and cellular homeostasis. Furthermore, it is widely
recognized that mitochondrial function and energy metabolism are
tightly regulated processes within cells. Therefore, lower concentrations
Figure 5. Neuroprotective effects of compounds against Iron (III)-induced cytotoxicity evaluated in differentiated SH-SY5Y cells 24 h after exposure to the aggressor
in the presence or absence of compounds. Results are presented as mean + SD from at least 5 independent experiments, performed in triplicate. Statistical com-
parisons were performed using the Two-way ANOVA followed by the Tukey's multiple comparisons test [ ### p < 0.001; #### p < 0.0001 vs. in the absence of Iron
(III); *p < 0.05, for comparisons between treatments [Iron (III) alone, Iron (III) + Compound (1, 2.5, 5 or 10 μM)], at each Iron (III) concentration].
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
of compound 7c may be more effective in maintaining the delicate
balance and homeostasis of these cellular processes, whereas higher
concentrations could disrupt this balance.
Overall, these studies led us to the identification of compounds with
relevant neuroprotective activity against cell death induced by a
neurotoxin that is selective for dopaminergic neurons, and which is
frequently used, in vitro and in vivo, to identify new disease-modifying
drugs with therapeutic potential in Parkinson's disease.
Neuroprotective effects against Iron (III)-induced cytotoxicity.
Iron is a trace element and one of the most abundant metals in the
human body. Iron homeostasis is achieved through the balance between
its absorption, use, storage, and excretion. Dysfunction of the iron levels
and neurodegenerative diseases are closely related. 41 Indeed, dysregu-
lation of iron metabolism can lead to an imbalance in the normal iron
redox status and in the levels of Fe 2+ , which can participate in the
Fenton reaction leading to a cycle between the two redox states, and to
the generation of •OH. 42 Furthermore, the increased production of ROS
leads to lipid peroxidation and ferroptosis, which was already reported
to be present in distinct neurodegenerative diseases. 41 In the present
study, the neuroprotective effects of compounds against iron (III)-
induced cytotoxicity were assessed, by the NR uptake assay, 24 h after
exposure of differentiated SH-SY5Y cells to the chemical aggressor (up to
1000 μM) in the presence or absence of non-cytotoxic concentrations of
the compounds under study (1, 2.5, 5 and 10 μM). Only the most
promising compounds identified as neuroprotective against MPP + -
induced cell death were selected, namely 1, 2 and 7c. All compounds
were tested at 1, 2.5 and 5 μM, except 7c which was also tested at 10 μM
given the lack of cytotoxic effects at this concentration. However, as
observed in Figure 5, only compound 1 slightly but significantly reduced
iron-induced cytotoxicity, being this neuroprotective effect observed
only for the lowest concentration of the aggressor and in the presence of
the lowest concentration of compound 1. Indeed, NR uptake signifi-
cantly increased to 87.6% 24 h after exposure to 500 μM iron (III) in the
presence of 1 μM of compound 1, when compared to 81.4% after
exposure to iron (III) alone. Although for 7c no significant differences
were detected upon exposure to iron (III), in the case of compound 2, at
2.5 or 5 μM, the cytotoxicity induced by the highest iron (III) concen-
tration was slightly but significantly increased.
Overall, and according to the obtained results, the developed 3-tet-
razolyl-β-carbolines demonstrated promising neuroprotective effects,
counteracting the cytotoxic effects induced by chemical stressors that
mimic pathophysiological hallmarks of Parkinson's disease. It is widely
accepted that MPP + induces cytotoxicity through mechanisms involving
oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and apoptosis. Specifically,
MPP + inhibits complex I of the mitochondrial electron transport chain,
leading to increased ROS production and a decline in ATP synthesis,
ultimately resulting in cell death. 38,39
Iron accumulation is another hallmark of distinct neurodegenerative
disease and in particular of Parkinson's disease pathology, specifically in
the substantia nigra. Iron overload can lead to oxidative stress and cell
death through mechanisms like ferroptosis, a form of regulated cell
death characterized by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. Several
hallmarks of ferroptosis were already identified in distinct neurode-
generative diseases including Parkinson's disease. 41
However, it should be highlighted that the developed 3-tetrazolyl-
β-carbolines demonstrated a higher potential in protecting neuronal
cells against MPP + -induced cytotoxicity, when compared to the neuro-
protective effects observed against iron-induced cytotoxicity. This sug-
gests that the studied 3-tetrazolyl-β-carboline derivatives may have
more potent and specific mechanisms to effectively counteract MPP + -
induced mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress (e.g. restoring
mitochondrial function, reducing oxidative damage, or promoting cell
survival pathways) compared to iron-mediated toxicity.
3. Conclusion
The synthesis of 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines and their activity as neu-
roprotective agents against Parkinson's disease has been reported. The
synthetic strategy involves the synthesis of a tryptophan analogue via
hetero-Diels-Alder reaction of a nitrosoalkene, 1-benzyl-5-(1-nitro-
sovinyl)-1H-tetrazole, and indole used as building block in the Pictet-
Spengler reaction with aromatic aldehydes followed by an oxidative
step.
The 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines were evaluated for their cytotoxicity
against differentiated SH-SY5Y cells, with multiple neuronal character-
istics, through two different methodologies (neutral red uptake and
resazurin reduction assays) allowing to conclude that for three of the
studied compounds concentrations up to 10 μM are non-cytotoxic
whereas for two derivatives the highest concentration considered non-
cytotoxic is 5 μM.
The evaluation of compounds' neuroprotective effects included the
study of the neuroprotective activity against MPP + -induced cell death, a
neurotoxin used to mimic Parkinson's disease. When differentiated SH-
SY5Y cells were exposed to MPP + in the presence of the compounds
under investigation, three of the 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines showed a
significant reduction in the cytotoxicity of the chemical aggressor. The
most promising compound, 3-(1-benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(p-dime-
thylaminophenyl)-β-carboline, led to a marked reduction in MPP + -
induced cytotoxicity, completely preventing the cell death induced by
the aggressor, even at a concentration 500 times lower than that of the
aggressor.
The compounds with the most promising neuroprotective activity
against MPP + -induced cell death were also evaluated for their neuro-
protective effect against iron (III)-induced cytotoxicity. However, only
one 3-tetrazolyl-β-carboline derivative slightly reduced iron-induced
cytotoxicity, although this neuroprotective effect was only observed at
the lowest concentration of the aggressor and in the presence of the
lowest concentration of this compound.
Overall, our results clearly highlight the neuroprotective potential of
new 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines. However, while three of the 3-tetrazolyl-
β-carbolines significantly reduced MPP + -induced cytotoxicity in SH-
SY5Y cells, only one of the developed compounds showed a slight
reduction in iron-induced toxicity. This suggests that the studied 3-tet-
razolyl-β-carbolines may have more potent and specific mechanisms to
effectively counteract MPP + -induced mitochondrial dysfunction and
oxidative stress (e.g. restoring mitochondrial function, reducing oxida-
tive damage, or promoting cell survival pathways) compared to iron-
mediated toxicity. Knowing that MPP + is a neurotoxin that selectively
targets and damages dopaminergic neurons, our work thus provides
evidence that 3-tetrazolyl-β-carbolines can be considered as potential
neuroprotective agents against Parkinson's disease, which is likely to
inspire the development of new Parkinson's disease therapies. There-
fore, further targeted research will be employed in the future to fully
elucidate the precise mechanism(s) underlying the observed 3-tetra-
zolyl-β-carbolines-mediated neuroprotection.
4. Experimental section
4.1. Chemistry
4.1.1. General information
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a
Bruker Avance III instrument operating at 400 MHz ( 1 H) or 100 MHz
( 13 C). Chemical shifts are expressed in parts per million with tetrame-
thylsilane (TMS) as internal standard, while coupling constants (J) are
expressed in Hz. Infrared spectra (IR) were recorded in a Fourier
Transform spectrometer coupled with a diamond Attenuated Total
Reflectance (ATR) sampling accessory. High-resolution mass spectra
(HRMS) were obtained on a TOF VG Autospect M spectrometer with
electrospray ionization (ESI). Melting points were determined in open
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
glass capillaries. Thin Layer Chromatography (TLC) was performed
using precoated silica gel plates. Flash chromatography was performed
using silica gel 60 as a stationary phase. Tryptamine 5 and 3-tetrazolyl-
β-carbolines 1 and 2 were prepared as described in the literature. 6
4.1.2. General procedure for the synthesis of tetrahydro-β-carbolines 6
Trifluoroacetic acid (2 equiv) was added to a solution of amine 5 (1
equiv) and the appropriate aldehyde (1 equiv) in dry dichloromethane
(23 mL/mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature,
and monitored by TLC until all the amine was consumed. Upon
completion, the reaction mixture was concentrated under reduced
pressure, the residue dissolved in ethyl acetate (10 mL) and neutralized
with an aqueous solution of Na 2 CO 3 10%. The resulting solution was
extracted with ethyl acetate (3 x 25 mL), dried over anhydrous Na 2 SO 4
and the solvent evaporated off. The products were purified by recrys-
tallization in MeOH and obtained as a mixture of cis/trans isomers, un-
less otherwise stated.
4.1.2.1. 3-(1-Benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(m-nitrophenyl)-2,3,4,9-tetrahy-
dro-β-carboline (6a). Obtained from the reaction of amine 5
(0.20 mmol, 65 mg) with m-nitrobenzaldehyde (0.20 mmol, 34 mg) as
described in the general procedure (reaction time: 28 h), as a mixture of
cis/trans isomers [61 mg, 84%, (40:60)]. Major component (trans-6a): IR
(ATR) ν: 742, 796, 1012, 1323, 1344, 1496, 1521, 3264 cm -1 . 1 H NMR
(Acetone-d 6 ) δ: 3.27 (dd, J = 15.0, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 3.42-3.48 (m, 1H), 4.39
(ddd, J = 14.0, 10.0, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 5.50 (d, J = 15.2 Hz, 1H), 5.57 (d,
J = 5.2 Hz, 1H), 5.58 (d, J = 15.2 Hz, 1H), 6.83-6.86 (m, 1H), 7.03-7.43
(m, 8H), 7.52-7.60 (m, 1H), 7.65-7.69 (m, 1H), 7.74-7.76 (m, 1H),
8.10-8.11 (m, 1H), 8.18-8.23 (m, 1H), 10.04 (s, 1H). HRMS (ESI-TOF)
m/z for C 25 H 21 N 7 O 2 Na [M+Na + ] calcd. 474.1649, found 474.1648.
4.1.2.2. 3-(1-Benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(o-chlorophenyl)-2,3,4,9-tetra-
hydro-β-carboline (6b). Obtained from the reaction of amine 5
(0.16 mmol, 50 mg) with o-chlorobenzaldehyde (0.16 mmol, 26 μL) as
described in the general procedure (reaction time: 40 h), as a mixture of
cis/trans isomers [52 mg, 70%, (50:50)]. Trans-6b: IR (ATR) ν: 749, 802,
1016, 1319, 1494, 3179 cm -1 . 1 H NMR (DMSO-d 6 ) δ: 3.09-3.26 (m,
2H), 4.21 (ddd, J = 14.8, 10.0, 4.4 Hz, 1H), 5.44 (d, J = 15.0 Hz, 1H),
5.54 (d, J = 15.0 Hz, 1H), 5.62 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H), 6.70-6.73 (m, 2H),
6.97-7.41 (m, 10H), 7.53-7.60 (m, 2H), 10.86 (s, 1H). HRMS (ESI-TOF)
m/z for C 25 H 21 N 6 ClNa [M+Na + ] calcd. 463.1408, found 463.1406.
4.1.2.3. 3-(1-Benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(p-dimethylaminophenyl)-
2,3,4,9-tetrahydro-β-carboline (6c). Obtained from the reaction of amine
5 (0.16 mmol, 50 mg) with p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde (0.16 mmol,
34 mg), as described in the general procedure (reaction time: 40 h), as
the trans-6c isomer [25 mg, 34%]. IR (ATR) ν: 745, 819, 1017, 1319,
1495, 1521, 3277 cm -1 . 1 H NMR (DMSO-d 6 ) δ: 2.87 (s, 6H), 3.12 (dd,
J = 15.4, 4.4 Hz, 1H), 3.63 (dd, J = 11.2, 4.4 Hz, 1H), 4.20 (ddd,
J = 15.4, 11.2, 4.4 Hz, 1H), 5.17 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H), 5.41 (d,
J = 14.8 Hz, 1H), 5.57 (d, J = 14.8 Hz, 1H), 6.72-6.76 (m, 4H),
6.97-7.08 (m, 4H), 7.16-7.20 (m, 2H), 7.23-7.29 (m, 2H), 7.49 (d,
J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 10.81 (s, 1H). 13 C NMR (DMSO-d 6 ) δ: 25.0, 40.3, 42.5,
48.6, 49.8, 54.0, 107.8, 111.1, 112.3, 117.7, 118.4, 120.9, 126.7, 127.9,
128.2, 128.6, 129.5, 129.8, 134.5, 136.0, 150.1, 155.9. HRMS (ESI-TOF)
m/z for C 27 H 28 N 7 [M-H + ] calcd. 450.2401, found 450.2399.
4.1.3. General procedure for the synthesis of β-carbolines 7
Sulphur powder (3 equiv) was added to a solution of the appropriate
tetrahydro-β-carboline 6 (1 equiv) in dimethylformamide (31 mL/
mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred under reflux for 24 h. After this
time, the solvent was evaporated off. The product was precipitated by
addition of diethyl ether, filtered, and dried under vacuum to give the
products in a pure form, unless otherwise stated.
4.1.3.1. 3-(1-Benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(m-nitrophenyl)-β-carboline
(7a). Obtained from tetrahydro-β-carboline 6a (0.16 mmol, 70 mg), as
described in the general procedure, as an off-white solid (43 mg, 62%).
mp 275.3-277.2 • C (from diethyl ether). IR (ATR) ν: 668, 729, 852,
1079, 1343, 1437, 1457 cm -1 . 1 H NMR (DMSO-d 6 ) δ: 6.32 (s, 2H),
7.18-7.21 (m, 2H), 7.25-7.27 (m, 3H), 7.38 (ddd, J = 8.0, 6.8, 1.2 Hz,
1H), 7.64-7.72 (m, 2H), 7.88 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.31 (dt, J = 8.4,
1.2 Hz, 1H), 8.40 (ddd, J = 8.0, 2.0, 0.8 Hz, 1H), 8.51 (d, J = 8.0 Hz,
1H), 8.72 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 9.18 (s, 1H), 12.14 (s, 1H). 13 C NMR
(DMSO-d 6 ) δ: 51.8, 112.7, 116.3, 120.7, 120.8, 122.5, 123.2, 123.7,
127.1, 127.9, 128.6, 129.4, 130.5, 130.6, 133.0, 133.8, 135.0, 135.6,
138.6, 139.8, 141.7, 148.2, 152.7. HRMS (ESI-TOF) m/z for
C 25 H 17 N 7 O 2 Na [M+Na + ] calcd. 470.1336, found 470.1330.
4.1.3.2. 3-(1-Benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(o-chlorophenyl)-β-carboline
(7b). Obtained from tetrahydro-β-carboline 6b (0.14 mmol, 60 mg), as
described in the general procedure, as a white solid (38 mg, 63%). mp
234.4-236.0 • C (from diethyl ether). IR (ATR) ν: 722, 799, 867, 1096,
1436, 1451 cm -1 . 1 H NMR (Acetone-d 6 ) δ: 6.29 (s, 2H), 7.19-7.22 (m,
3H), 7.24-7.26 (m, 2H), 7.39 (ddd, J = 8.0, 6.4, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.57-7.65
(m, 4H), 7.67-7.70 (m, 2H), 8.48 (dd, J = 8.0, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 9.12 (s, 1H),
10.93 (br s, 1H). 13 C NMR (Acetone-d 6 ) δ: 53.0, 113.2, 116.6, 121.6,
122.4, 123.1, 128.4, 128.8, 129.0, 129.4, 130.2, 130.9, 131.6, 132.8,
133.9, 134.5, 135.9, 136.9, 137.3, 142.2, 142.6, 153.6. HRMS (ESI-TOF)
m/z for C 25 H 18 N 6 Cl [M+H + ] calcd. 437.1276, found 437.1269.
4.1.3.3. 3-(1-Benzyl-1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1-(p-dimethylaminophenyl)-β-car-
boline (7c). Obtained from tetrahydro-β-carboline 6c (0.09 mmol,
40 mg), as described in the general procedure, as a white solid (24 mg,
56%). mp 259.1-261.2 • C (from diethyl ether). IR (ATR) ν: 693, 723,
846, 1091, 1363, 1429, 1444 cm -1 . 1 H NMR (DMSO-d 6 ) δ: 3.06 (s, 6H),
6.49 (s, 2H), 6.88-6.92 (m, 2H), 7.25-7.31 (m, 5H), 7.37 (ddd, J = 8.0,
6.8, 0.8 Hz, 1H), 7.61 (ddd, J = 8.4, 7.2, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 7.74 (d, J = 8.4 Hz,
1H), 7.90-7.94 (m, 2H), 8.43 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.96 (s, 1H), 11.09 (br
s, 1H). 13 C NMR (DMSO-d 6 ) δ: 34.4, 51.7, 112.3, 112.9, 114.2, 120.3,
120.6, 121.0, 122.1, 122.5, 127.4, 127.9, 128.0, 128.8, 129.3, 129.5,
132.7, 133.1, 135.9, 141.5, 150.8, 152.9. HRMS (ESI-TOF) m/z for
C 27 H 24 N 7 [M+H + ] calcd. 446.2088, found 446.2077.
4.2. Biological studies
4.2.1. Materials
The human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cell line was obtained from the
American Type Culture Collection (ATCC; Manassas, VA, USA). Anti-
biotic mixture (10 000 U/mL penicillin, 10 000 μg/mL streptomycin),
non-essential amino acids (NEAA) and Hanks' balanced salt solution
(HBSS) with or without calcium and magnesium [HBSS (+/+) or HBSS
(-/-), respectively] were obtained from PanBiotech (Germany). Heat
inactivated fetal bovine serum (FBS) was obtained from Gibco (United
Kingdom). Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium with high glucose and
sodium bicarbonate, as well as trypsin-ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid
(EDTA) solution (0.25% trypsin/1 mM EDTA), phorbol 12-myristate 13-
acetate (TPA), neutral red (NR) solution, resazurin (REZ), 1-methyl-4-
phenylpyridinium (MPP + ), iron (III) chloride (FeCl 3 ), nitrilotriacetic
acid disodium salt (Na 2 NTA), nitrilotriacetic acid trisodium salt
(Na 3 NTA), 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescin diacetate (DCFH-DA), tert-Butyl hy-
droperoxide (t-BHP) and retinoic acid (RA) were obtained from Sigma-
Aldrich (Germany). Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was obtained from
Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). All the sterile plastic material that was
used was acquired from Corning Costar (Glendale, AZ, USA). The puri-
fied water that was used in all the experiments was obtained from a
Direct-Q® Ultrapure Water Systems, Merck Millipore (Darmstadt, Ger-
many). All the reagents used were of analytical grade or of the highest
grade available.
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
4.2.2. Methods
SH-SY5Y cells -cell culture and differentiation
The SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cell line can be manipulated using
several protocols of terminal neural differentiation, which enable the
cells to acquire multiple neuronal characteristics, including the devel-
opment of neurite-like processes, the establishment of functional syn-
apses, heightened electrical excitability of the cell membrane, and the
induction of neuron-specific enzymes, neurotransmitters, and neuro-
transmitter receptors. 43 In our study, the differentiation of SH-SY5Y cells
was induced by supplementing the cell culture medium with retinoic
acid (RA) and 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (TPA), following a
well-established protocol. 44 This approach led to a robust differentiation
of SH-SY5Y cells into a dopaminergic phenotype, as evidenced by a
significant increase in the expression of dopamine transporter (DAT) and
tyrosine hydroxylase (TH). 44
The cells were regularly grown in 25 cm 2 cell culture flasks, in
Dulbecco's Modified Eagle's Medium containing 4.5 g per liter of
glucose, supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 1% anti-
biotic mixture (100 U/mL penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin), and
1% MEM non-essential amino acids. The cells were maintained in a
controlled environment with 5% CO 2 and 95% O 2 at a temperature of
37 • C to ensure optimal cell growth. When cell confluence reached
80-90%, cultures were passed weekly by trypsinization (0.25% trypsin/
1 mM EDTA). For all experiments, the cells were seeded in sterile 96-
well plates at a density of 25,000 cells/cm 2 . To promote cell differen-
tiation, the cells were seeded in complete cell culture medium con-
taining RA at a final concentration of 10 μM. After three days, TPA was
added to each well at a final concentration of 80 nM to further enhance
cell differentiation. Six days after seeding, the cells were used in the
experiments. The cells used in all the experiments were taken between
the 20th and 28th passages.
Evaluation of the Compounds' Cytotoxicity.
The cytotoxicity of developed compounds towards differentiated SH-
SY5Y cells was firstly assessed, by using the resazurin (REZ) reduction
and neutral red uptake assays, 24 h after exposure, aiming to select non
cytotoxic concentrations to be used in the evaluation of their potential
neuroprotective effects. For that purpose, six days after seeding, differ-
entiated SH-SY5Y cells were exposed to several concentrations of the
compounds under study, in concentrations ranging from 0 to 50 μM, for
24 h, at 37 • C and in a 5% CO 2 -95% O 2 air atmosphere. Triton™ X-100
(1%) was used as positive control.
Resazurin reduction assay.
The resazurin (REZ) reduction assay finds widespread utility across a
variety of applications, encompassing investigations into cell viability,
cell proliferation, and cytotoxicity. This redox dye serves as an indicator
of the active metabolism within cell cultures and relies on the intracel-
lular conversion of resazurin into resorufin by metabolically active cells.
Initially, the resazurin solution presents itself as a blue-colored solution
with minimal intrinsic fluorescence. As resazurin permeates through cell
membranes, it is metabolically reduced by viable cells producing the
fluorescent, pink-coloured counterpart, resorufin, which is likewise able
to traverse cell membranes. The amount of formed resorufin is thus an
indicative of the number of metabolically viable cells in culture. 32,33
After exposure of differentiated SH-SY5Y cells to the compounds for
24 h, the cell culture medium was removed and the cells were incubated
with REZ (10 μg/mL, prepared in fresh cell culture medium), at 37 • C, in
a humidified 5% CO 2 -95% O 2 air atmosphere, for 90 min. The fluo-
rescence was read afterwards in a multiwell plate reader (PowerWaveX
BioTek Instruments, Vermont, US), using excitation and emission
wavelengths of 560 nm and 590 nm, respectively. The percentage of REZ
reduction relative to that of the control cells (DMSO) was used as the
cytotoxicity measure. Five independent experiments were performed, in
triplicate.
NR uptake assay.
The NR uptake assay is a cytotoxicity and viability assay that relies
on the capacity of living cells to bind and incorporate the NR dye within
their lysosomes. This method is notably straightforward and swift,
yielding dependable outcomes for quantifying the number of viable cells
in a culture. The amount of NR dye incorporated by the cells thus serves
as an indicator of their lysosomal activity, offering a means to distin-
guish between viable, impaired, or deceased cells. 34,35
After exposure of differentiated SH-SY5Y cells to the compounds for
24 h, the cell culture medium was removed and the cells incubated with
NR (50 μg/mL, prepared in fresh cell culture medium), at 37 • C, in a
humidified 5% CO 2 -95% O 2 air atmosphere, for 90 min. After this
incubation period, the cell culture medium was removed, the cells
washed with HBSS (+/+) and the dye absorbed only by viable cells
extracted with ethyl alcohol absolute/distilled water (1:1) with 5%
acetic acid. The absorbance was then measured at 540 nm in a multiwell
plate reader (PowerWaveX BioTek Instruments, Vermont, US). The
percentage of NR uptake relative to that of the control cells (DMSO) was
used as the cytotoxicity measure. Five independent experiments were
performed, in triplicate.
Quantification of ROS intracellular levels.
The potential of the compounds under study to increase the intra-
cellular levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS), and consequently to
induce oxidative stress, was also assessed 24 h after exposure using the
cell permeant probe 2′-7′dichlorofluorescin diacetate (DCFH-DA)]. Upon
entering the cells, DCFH-DA is cleaved cellular esterases generating
DCFH. Subsequent oxidation of DCFH by ROS results in the production
of the fluorescent 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein (DCF). Consequently, the
intensity of DCF fluorescence serves as an indicator of the intracellular
ROS levels, where a higher fluorescence intensity corresponds to
elevated ROS levels. 36
SH-SY5Y cells were seeded into 96-well plates and submitted to
dopaminergic differentiation as previously described. Six days after
seeding, differentiated SH-SY5Y cells were pre-incubated with DCFH-DA
(10 µM), for 1 h, at 37 • C, in a humidified 5% CO2 -95% air atmosphere.
Then, the cell culture was removed, and the cells exposed to the com-
pounds under study (0---50 µM) for 24 h. Tert-butyl hydroperoxide (t-
BHP, 100 µM, 24 h) was used as a positive control of ROS over-
production. After exposure, ROS intracellular levels were assessed by
measuring DCF fluorescence, in a multiwell plate reader (PowerWaveX
BioTekInstruments, Vermont, USA), using an excitation wavelength of
485 nm and an emission wavelength of 590 nm. Results were expressed
as percentage of control cells (untreated cells).
Evaluation of the Compounds' Neuroprotective Effects.
The potential neuroprotective effects of the developed compounds
were assessed in differentiated SH-SY5Y cells against different chemical
aggressors, such as 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium (MPP + , the active
metabolite of MPTP, a dopaminergic neurotoxin that produces features
of Parkinson's disease in humans), and iron (III) [in the form of an iron
(III)-nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) complex (FeNTA), to simulate iron
overload].
Protective Effects against MPP + -Induced Cytotoxicity.
To evaluate the potential protective effect of the compounds against
MPP + -induced cytotoxicity, SH-SY5Y cells were seeded (at a density of
25,000 cells/cm 2 ) into 96-well plates and submitted to dopaminergic
differentiation, as previously described. Six days after seeding, a fresh
stock solution of MPP + was prepared in HBSS (+/+), which was diluted
afterwards in fresh cell culture medium to the desired concentrations
and used immediately. Differentiated SH-SY5Y cells were then pre-
exposed to the compounds under study (1, 2.5, 5 and 10 μM) prepared
in fresh cell culture medium. After 30 min of pre-incubation, MPP + (500
and 1000 μM) was added, and the cells further incubated, at 37 • C, in a
humidified 5% CO 2 -95% air atmosphere, for 24 h. After the incubation
period, cell viability was evaluated using the NR uptake assay, as pre-
viously described. At least five independent experiments were per-
formed, in triplicate.
Protective Effects against Iron (III)-Induced Cytotoxicity.
The potential protective effect of the compounds against iron (III)-
induced cytotoxicity were assessed upon exposure of differentiated SH-
text.note:
J.L.P. Ribeiro et al.
Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry 111 (2024) 117841
text.body:
SY5Y cells to ferric nitrilotriacetate (FeNTA). FeNTA results from the
solubilization of iron (III) in nitrilotriacetic acid, providing an iron (III)-
NTA complex that facilitates iron entrance into the cells. Also, this
complex prevents the hydrolysis of iron (III) at physiological pH and has
been widely used as an iron supply for numerous biological studies. 37
Firstly, a NTA (250 mM, pH 7.4) solution was prepared by combining a
Na 2 NTA solution (100 mM) and a Na 3 NTA solution (100 mM) until
pH = 7 was reached. Thereafter, iron (III) chloride was weighed to the
NTA solution, to obtain a 50 mM FeNTA stock solution. In each exper-
iment, a new FeNTA stock solution was freshly prepared, kept protected
from light and stabilized for 15 min before being used to ensure the
complete formation of the ferric oxidation form before addition to the
cell cultures, and then diluted in fresh cell culture medium to obtain the
desired concentrations.
Briefly, SH-SY5Y cells were seeded at a density of 25,000 cells/cm 2
and submitted to dopaminergic differentiation, as previously described.
Six days after seeding, differentiated SH-SY5Y cells were pre-exposed to
the compounds under study (1, 2.5, 5 and 10 μM), prepared in fresh cell
culture medium. After 30 min of pre-incubation, FeNTA (500 and
1000 μM) was added, and the cells were further incubated, at 37 • C, in a
humidified 5% CO 2 -95% air atmosphere, for 24 h. After the incubation
period, cell viability was evaluated using the NR uptake assay, as pre-
viously described. At least five independent experiments were per-
formed, in triplicate.
Statistical Analysis.
The statistical analysis was performed using GraphPad Prism 9 for
Windows (GraphPad Software, USA). The normality of the data distri-
bution was assessed using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov, D'Agostino &
Pearson omnibus, and Shapiro-Wilk normality tests. In the evaluation of
compounds cytotoxicity, One-way ANOVA was used to perform the
statistical comparisons, followed by the Dunnett's multiple comparisons
test. In the evaluation of the compound's neuroprotective effects, two-
way ANOVA was used to compare means of different groups, followed
by the Tukey's multiple comparisons test. In all cases, p values smaller
than 0.05 were considered significant.
CRediT authorship contribution statement
João L.P. Ribeiro: Writing -original draft, Investigation, Formal
analysis. Inês Costa: Writing -original draft, Investigation. Renata
Silva: Writing -review & editing, Supervision, Formal analysis. Susana
M.M. Lopes: Writing -review & editing, Supervision, Formal analysis.
Lucília Saraiva: Writing -review & editing, Supervision, Formal
analysis, Conceptualization. Teresa M.V.D. Pinho e Melo: Writing -
review & editing, Supervision, Formal analysis, Conceptualization.
Declaration of competing interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial
interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence
the work reported in this paper.
text.div:
Data availability
Data will be made available on request.

Acknowledgements
The Coimbra Chemistry Centre-Institute of Molecular Sciences
(CQC-IMS) and LAQV/REQUIMTE are supported by Portuguese Foun-
dation for Science and Technology (FCT) through projects UIDB/00313/
2020 (http://doi.org/10.54499/UIDB/00313/2020), UIDP/00313/
2020 (http://doi.org/10.54499/UIDP/00313/2020), UIDP/50006/
2020 (http://doi.org/10.54499/UIDP/50006/2020) and UIDB/50006/
2020 (http://doi.org/10.54499/UIDB/50006/2020) (National Funds),
and the IMS (LA/P/0056/2020, http://doi.org/10.54499/LA/P/0056/
2020) and LAQV/REQUIMTE (LA/P/0008/2020, http://doi.org/
10.54499/LA/P/0008/2020) special complementary funds. The authors
João L. P. Ribeiro (PD/BD/143160/2019, MedChemTrain programme)
and Susana M. M. Lopes (DL57/2016/CP1370/CT0057, http://doi.org/
10.54499/DL57/2016/CP1370/CT0057) also thank FCT for their indi-
vidual support. Laboratory of Toxicology, Department of Biological
Sciences of Faculty of Pharmacy of University od Porto, was funded by
national funds from FCT -Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia, I.P.,
in the scope of the project UIDP/04378/2020 and UIDB/04378/2020 of
the Research Unit on Applied Molecular Biosciences -UCIBIO and the
project LA/P/0140/2020 of the Associate Laboratory Institute for
Health and Bioeconomy -i4HB. The authors acknowledge the UC-NMR
facility for obtaining the NMR data (https://www.uc.pt/uc-nmr/).

Appendix A. Supplementary material
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.
org/10.1016/j.bmc.2024.117841.
